item.title: South Sudan’s Fourth Anniversary Offers Little to Celebrate
item.description: Independence was greeted with great hope in 2011 but now rings hollow for many as their country descends further into division and misery.
item.dc:creator: MARC SANTORA
item.media:description: A market in Juba, South Sudan. Prices are rising as the country's economy struggles.

item.title: A Migrant Mother’s Anguished Choice
item.description: Lost in the diplomatic wrangling over the fate of the Rohingya fleeing Myanmar are the harrowing personal consequences.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS BUCKLEY and THOMAS FULLER
item.media:credit: Tomas Munita for The New York Times
item.media:description: Jubair, 13, was left behind when his mother and siblings fled Myanmar for Malaysia. “I didn’t know about it,” he said. “She could not find me. She could not tell me.”

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: China Finds Another Real-Life Spinoff of ‘Breaking Bad’
item.description: Officials have arrested a chemistry professor suspected of producing and selling a psychoactive drug, and the state news agency is calling him “China’s real-life Walter White.”
item.dc:creator: EDWARD WONG
item.media:description: Bryan Cranston as Walter White in the series "Breaking Bad."

item.title: Greece Said to Delay Offering New Plan on Debt
item.description: As eurozone finance ministers met in Brussels, the new Greek finance minister is said to have arrived without a new bailout proposal.
item.dc:creator: JAMES KANTER
item.media:description: Greeks caught up with the news in Athens on Tuesday, ahead of an emergency summit meeting of European leaders.

item.title: Taliban Leaders Are Said to Meet With Afghan Officials
item.description: The Taliban has rejected face-to-face talks for years, and officials hope Tuesday’s meeting is a step toward negotiations to end the Afghan war.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: JOSEPH GOLDSTEIN
item.media:description: Afghan security forces after an attack by Taliban insurgents on a compound used by Afghanistan's intelligence agency in Kabul on Tuesday.

item.title: Code Specialists Oppose U.S. and British Government Access to Encrypted Communication
item.description: A new report says giving the governments “exceptional access” to encrypted communications would jeopardize confidential data and critical infrastructure.
item.dc:creator: NICOLE PERLROTH
item.media:description: Peter G. Neumann, a computer security pioneer, says “there are more vulnerabilities than ever" that could be exploited through access to encrypted communications.

item.title: Iran Nuclear Talks Are Extended Once Again
item.description: Negotiations to complete an accord limiting the country’s nuclear program will continue for several more days after representatives acknowledged that they would be unable to meet a Tuesday deadline.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL R. GORDON

item.title: Rohingya Family’s Plight Prompts Offers of Aid
item.description: The story about a family from Myanmar that was torn apart during a regional migration crisis elicited a huge response from readers, but most of their offers are impossible to fulfill.
item.category: United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees
item.dc:creator: CHRIS BUCKLEY
item.media:credit: Tomas Munita for The New York Times
item.media:description: Jubair, 13, was left behind when his mother and siblings fled Myanmar for Malaysia. “I didn’t know about it,” he said. “She could not find me. She could not tell me.”

item.title: Islamic Battalions, Stocked With Chechens, Aid Ukraine in War With Rebels
item.description: Acknowledging Moscow as an enemy shared with Kiev, one leader from Chechnya said, “We never ran from our war with Russia, and we never will.”
item.dc:creator: ANDREW E. KRAMER
item.media:description: Members of a Chechen battalion fighting against Russian-backed rebels in Lysychansk, Ukraine, in February.

item.title: 3 North Korean Sailors Defect to South After Ship Strays
item.description: They told South Korean officials that they wanted to defect, while two others expressed wishes to return home, the South’s Unification Ministry said.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: 10 Years After London Bombings, Warnings of a Greater Threat
item.description: As the country mourned the 52 civilians who were killed, government officials warned that the peril of terrorism had increased, though its nature has shifted.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: STEVEN ERLANGER
item.media:description: Prime Minister David Cameron of Britain, right, and Mayor Boris Johnson of London laid wreaths on Tuesday at a memorial in Hyde Park to the victims of the London bombings on July 7, 2005.

item.title: Inquiry Into Malaysian Fund Also Puts Spotlight on Prime Minister
item.description: Prime Minister Najib Razak is facing accusations that some money from the heavily indebted 1Malaysia Development Berhad has been routed to accounts controlled by him.
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:description: Prime Minister Najib Razak of Malaysia. News reports have said that some of 1Malaysia Development Berhad's funds have been routed to accounts controlled by Mr. Najib.

item.title: NATO Convoy in Afghanistan Is Struck by Suicide Car Bomb
item.description: At least four civilians were wounded in the second such attack in the past week against coalition soldiers in the capital, Kabul.
item.dc:creator: MUJIB MASHAL
item.media:description: At least four civilians were wounded in the attack in Kabul, the Afghan capital, on Tuesday.

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Losing Leverage on Bahrain
item.description: If the U.S. knows how bad the Persian Gulf state’s human rights record is, why renew military aid?
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: SAYED ALWADAEI

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Found in Translation
item.description: Bringing foreign language writers into the crowded realm of English only enriches the world of literature.
item.dc:creator: BENJAMIN MOSER

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Xi Jinping of China Makes Cartoon Appearance Before Meetings in Russia
item.description: The short explains the significance of the BRICS nations — Brazil, Russia, India, China and South Africa — and the Shanghai Cooperation Organization, which includes China, Russia and four Central Asian countries.
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Q. and A.: Xie Shi on the Brotherhood of Skateboarding in China’s Far West
item.description: The photographer and skateboarder based in Nanjing says that the skateboarding scene in Xinjiang is both ethnically diverse and more harmonious than the mainstream of society.
item.dc:creator: VANESSA PIAO
item.media:description: Skateboarding in the Pamir Mountains in the Xinjiang region of China.

item.title: Letter From America: Germany Has Lessons for the South
item.description: As arguments over the Confederate flag have shown, Germany and the American South have different stories about defeated racist ideologies.
item.dc:creator: ANAND GIRIDHARADAS

item.title: Somali Militants Carry Out Deadly Attack in Northeast Kenya
item.description: Shabab fighters killed 14 people and wounded 11 in the town of Mandera, a government official said, the latest attack in the region by the Islamist group.
item.dc:creator: ISMA’IL KUSHKUSH

item.title: Iraqi Forces Plan Offensive to Retake Ramadi From ISIS
item.description: President Obama said the fall of the key western city had galvanized the Iraqi government and accelerated an American effort to train forces there.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL R. GORDON and ERIC SCHMITT
item.media:description: Members of Iraq's Shiite militia and security forces gathered on Monday in Anbar Province.
